review_title: Lovely Vibrant Workplace with Passionate, Creative Colleagues

Management team and even the support functions exhibit impressive passion for their role. It's a place with lots of potential for growth given the mission of the Organisation. Management supports Job Rotation and Internal Lateral moves, which is a great way for retaining youths to explore their career aspiration and development. Reasonably good benefits compared to other SMEs/ Non Profit. It is a place that value and require Team Success. Individuals who are focus on own agenda/KPIs and running their own race may not be a good help in building the team/ organisation's success.
cons: No Cons. This is a place to thrive and be progressive. Hence it may not suit those: looking to slow down in life/take it easy; or lacking self awareness/openness for opportunities to better themselves; or lacking capabilities in people development.

pros: The building is originally set to do good work, engaging and directing the youths of Singapore.
cons:
Management has changed and the work environment is now toxic. The management team has a shallow understanding of what they are doing and has regressed to issues explored over 4 yrs ago, without actually reviewing or valuing past findings and experiences. The environment is toxic because elements are now clambering to claim credit for things they have not done or lay blame on other people.

Organisational memory has been lost, forgetting what strategic partner entities have been contributing out of goodwill in the past and blind to the real value of what partner entities can contribute in the future.

Management has been so bad that, all their mid-level executional managers have left in the last 6 months, and close to half of their on the ground staff have left and more are in the process of looking to leave. New management has only been in place officially for less than 6 months. But hey it may be a strategy to get rid of "old blood" right? Or just plain simple mismanagement. Many people who work at *SCAPE are not there for the money, salary is pretty low, so for them to throw in the towel, it says alot about what they are putting up with.

*SCAPE now chases after shallow wayang KPIs and media sexy stuff, which is scary for a government supported and directed entity. Instead of looking deeper and dealing with the real issues that affect youths in Singapore, which it used to have a heart for, it now focuses on hitting "KPIs" which help them look good to the various government agencies and personas they report to. Examples would include:

1. Measuring youth engagement by counting social media likes, or incentivising people to fill out forms, so they have have numbers to show the brass. They are already aware of better ways to do this and should know real engagement comes from tracking loyalty, which they might be worried to expose to the brass.

2. There is a shallow drive to pull in "sexy" topics like A.I., robots and vending machine retail concepts, just because it looks and sounds good at this point in time. There is no deeper thought to how this integrates back to youth outreach, engagement and capability building.

- Management as doesnt honour staff's off days and expects immediate work to be produced from staff even after working hours
- Management does not honour staff's opinions and easily shrugs off need for improvements raised by staff

job_title: Social Worker in Tampines New Town,
pros: good environment, kind bosses and colleagues
cons: emotionally taxing at times but still ok

pros:
- A good start off career environment into residential care setting in Singapore.

- A supporting group of ground staff that is always there for you when you need guidance and support.

- A good environment to challenge one self to take up more responsibility and going to extreme ends to reach out to youths.

- Catered food for your shift.

- Great support given between inter ground staff.

- Opportunities of conducting programs (If you want to have a taste of how it is).

- Exposure to different profile if clientele. (Perfect learning ground for behaviour analysis amongst children and youth.)
cons:
- Limited career progression amongst ground staff (limit to one or two only amongst different care department.)

- Scrutiny (Be prepared to be questioned for all of the things that you do, but if you know what you are doing, stand your ground and you are good).

- Shift hours (Night shift can be a night mare at times).

- Lack of follow up amongst upper management and other departments.

- Be prepared to contribute more and be less affirmed. (Be expected to do things more out of sincerity than depending on getting recognised. If you are that kind of person, maybe not the best of place.)

review_title: Great place to work but with low pay
cons: very low pay and poor HR

review_title: It was a good place to work but there's need for improvement all around.
pros:
Rotation shift that fitted my needs well. 
A lot of time to understand today's youths and their needs.
A good place to learn the dos and don'ts of social work. 
A place where even staffs whom made mistakes are given opportunities to shine again. 
A staff dormitory that allows direct service staffs to stay over, on duty or not and develop a good camaraderie.
cons:
Low income. 

Direct Servicem Staffs are made to do a lot of work in addition to their long hours of services (ticket sales, St Joseph Feast Day etc) without the encouragement, support and eventual financial returns. There weren't even off in lieu that were honoured.

There were times of favoritism.

A lack of good and proper HR practices. Though Boys' Town Singapore is a social service institute, there are a lot of good things that could be learnt from the corporate world that should be incorporated.

review_title: Find Meaningful work and you'll get it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bukit Merah Estate,
pros:
It's been about almost 10 years since i worked here. Back then, i didn't understand the value of my work and what my work meant to the boys/residents there. 10 years now after i have left, i see the value of it when i meet boys that have graduated from BT. They come calling out your name and sharing with you how their lives are like now and how grateful they are that you were there for them on your best and worse days. You cannot understand the value of your work until you see the fruition of it years from now. This is what is means to impact lives. It doesn't happen overnight. It takes time even when you feel that you are not doing anything great at some point, which most of the staff have been there and felt that. 
I've gone on to commercial work for personal reasons, but i can tell you that that feeling when you see the kids outside years from now makes you realize how meaningful your job can be. i really miss being there for the boys even when i feel like smacking them silly.
cons: I never agreed about everything with the management from A to Z. But they are there to build lives. Not everything will go your way as with any place, but you got to find that sweet spot which gives you the most satisfaction. Dealing with the boys can be really stressful if you are in program supervision of some sort. Talk to the bosses, go all the way up to have a sincere conversation if you need to. Be straightforward. They can exercise compassion and try to be flexible and talk it through with you. Just don't be abusive. Be genuine and have good ego strength (or try). And if you really feel its time to move on, then go in peace and go out there and achieve new things. Brother Emmanuel would wish you well even despite how you feel. You might move on but the work continues. But maybe, just maybe, you'll come back and feel different. Time will tell.

review_title: Overall a good institution but one specific department sorely needs to be revamped
pros:
- Caring and patient Executive Director (the CEO equivalent for this organisation)

- Caring and knowledgeable Discipline Master for the clients, who is also a veteran of the organisation

- Highly efficient and effective corporate services team

- Some members of the management team are truly outstanding in their field and performance (e.g. the Deputy Director for Social Work, or the HR & Governance Specialist), not just impressive on paper. There is plenty to learn from them

- Family-style atmosphere

- Own building, thus no need to share facilities with other companies

- Values experience and competence rather than just paper qualifications

- Reasonably good overall benefit package for a non-profit organisation
cons:
- While the corporate services team is highly efficient and  effective, the same cannot be said about a certain other department, although there are a scarce few exceptional individuals amongst them. 

- Someone who had just left the organisation changed the way clients are looked after to become no different from a military correctional facility during his stint. Hopefully the new HoD who had joined recently can clean up the mess and bring positive changes. 

- Uneven distribution of staff perks (not the management's fault). Some people reserve perks almost exclusively for their own department and their relatives with ludicrous excuses, instead of opening it up for fair distribution after assigning the necessary care ratio.

- Unacceptable staff behaviour (yes, that same department again) towards the clients is hardly reined in nor chastised openly, nor ensured to be corrected. Many of them have insufferable egos and do not view the clients favourably.

- Extremely harsh punishment (often had to be mitigated by the much more level-headed Discipline Master, who draws flak from behind him from certain staff for doing what is right) recommended and dealt out upon clients and made openly known, especially when it involves bad attitude towards staff, even when the staff in question instigated the negative response.

pros:
- Moderately satisfactory medical benefits.
- Reasonable "flexi-benefits" up to $400 depending on position.
cons:
- Inconvenient location.
- Ineffective performance appraisal process where rater bias features heavily.
- Over-emphasis on religion-based values. As a result incompetent staff are able to pass off by putting up a corresponding facade or playing the right political cards.
- Staff are not rewarded based on quantifiable work performance.
- Lacking in promotion prospects.
- Staff are often required by mandatory management orders to participate in non-job scope extraneous "duties" with attached quotas, such as fundraising by non-fundraiser staff members.
- Scarce external training opportunities/budgets.
